page.title: 09ELECTRICITY SUB-STATIONS
page.content: Electricity comes to our homes from a power station. The electrical pressure in the wires is controlled by the output of the generators and by sub-stations along the route. At Hodgetts Lane is a sub-station which feeds electricity to the national Grid system. This sub-station operates at 275,000 and 400,000 volts. The electricity from here is carried to Grid supply points by means of overhead transmission lines suspended from transmossion towers. Sometimes in built-up areas underground cables are used instead of overhead lines. Tanners Lane sub-station is a bulk supply point and this reduces the voltage to 11,000 volts. The 11,000 volt cables then go to sub-stations where the voltage is again transformed to 240 volts for direct use in shops, schools, homes and factories.
